title: Re: Most dangerous Keen enemy?
content:
What we must balance here is singular dangerousness with total dangerousness.

For example, Boobus tuber beats Robo red; taking more hits, being smarter and more mobile. However, there is only one BT and many RR's, so in general you will be killed more by Red, making him more dangerous in total.

I vote for the Shikadai master, for, if there were many of him he would make the levels virtually impossible. [:/hide comment from KeenRush]

If say, the Foobs ran toward you, and killed, and there were dozens of them, then they could be the most feared enemy in Keen, attacking in herds and cutting Keen down where he stood. [The third patchwork mod has this patch]

Difficult, difficult...

A proud member of the Spleen Extinction society

-Levellord

title: well...
content:
Placement is everything when it comes to an enemy's danger level, though. Many of the Vortininjas are located in a way that makes Ankh use strategic (and necessary) to complete the level. Skypests, on the other hand, are often placed in such a way that the player needs to completely halt their progress or risk certain death (hello Pyramid of the Forbidden)...

Sometimes a simple enemy will be placed in a hard location, like the Fleex before the exit to BASA on Hard mode (I think it was BASA--but might be Guard Post III). Other times an enemy can be a cakewalk because it's put in a location which doesn't matter (the Spirogrip in the Gravitational Dampening Hub) or is hard to get to.

I think, in the long run, Meeps are the single enemy I loathe the most simply because of what happens when they walk off a cliff. The noise, the spamming of deadly shots, and the complete inability to defend against it... it's just not fair.

title: Re: Most dangerous Keen enemy?
content: "beat" instead of "beaten" is American slang.  Like when they say you should "eat healthy" instead of "eat healthily", as if "healthy" is some object you can literally eat.  It's not really wrong, but it'll annoy all the English teachers out there.

title: Re: Most dangerous Keen enemy?
content:
Anything in common use is part of the syntax of a language and cannot be wrong. As Nexus says:

AINT: Simple, commonly used, easy to understand and versitile, therefore utterly not allowed in reports.
